{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the patient's presentation and physical examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased pressure in the chest cavity. This can cause compression of the heart and great vessels, leading to decreased cardiac output and hypotension. The muffled heart sounds and jugular venous distention are consistent with cardiac tamponade, which can occur as a result of increased pressure in the chest. Tracheal deviation toward the right side is not likely in this case, as there are no signs of a large pneumothorax or hemothorax. Hemoptysis is the coughing up of blood, which is not a typical finding in tension pneumothorax. Paradoxical motion of part of the chest with breathing is seen in flail chest, which is caused by multiple rib fractures.
